entry.title: Digital TV: Not so hard after all
entry.content:
On July 24, when Japanese TV stations stopped analog broadcasts, I’d done nothing to get our TV system digital-ready. I’m not the biggest TV fan. The prospect of not having it for a while was about as daunting as imagining life without SPAM. I reckoned I’d have to pay for a tuner, an antenna, and for someone to come out and install it. I was sure it would be expensive, time consuming and end up with me feeling somehow ripped off.

We were in Australia at the end of July so it wasn’t an immediate problem. And even when we got back at the end of the month it was fine. If the kids wanted to watch something really badly they went to their grandmother’s house and watched it there. I knew it was something I’d have to take care of someday, though. On a Sunday near the end of August I took a deep breath and decided to do what needed doing.

Less than an hour later we were up and running. It didn’t cost a thing.

The first happy surprise was finding out that our TV, though rather old, was already digital-ready. That meant I wouldn’t have to get a tuner.

I headed out to the balcony to take a look at the antenna and wiring. I was somewhat incredulous when I saw that there was actually a UHF antenna perched on top of the VHF one.

Where did that come from? I know I didn’t buy it. It must’ve been sitting there unused and unloved since we bought the house twelve years ago.

Twenty minutes later, after messing about with cables and TV settings a bit, we were good to go. All the noisy variety shows, irksome melodramas, and screechy singing programs you could ever hope to watch were back for our viewing pleasure in vibrant high-definition.

entry.title: Daughter in Desert
Why does Lion switch away from full-screen apps on wake?
entry.content:
What’s going on here?

When I put my MacBook to sleep, Safari (in full-screen) is the active application. When I wake it up it immediately switches to the Finder or some other non-full-screen app.

The same thing happens with every other full-screen app.

I’ve asked the kids, my wife, and the cat and none of us can come up with a reason why that should happen.

Bug? Feature? Just me?

— Update: August 12—

I learned today that switching on wake doesn’t only happen with full-screen apps. It happens all the time. That the internet is not aflame with complaints about this (I can find none) makes me suspect that the problem is local. But I installed Lion on top of a pristine Snow Leopard. What more can I do?

entry.title: Can Cats Learn?
entry.content:
Every time our cat slips through our defenses and gets outside she sets to eating some leaves. When she comes back she invariably throws up the leaves and whatever else is in her stomach. She doesn’t seem to enjoy it very much.

You may not be able to teach an old dog new tricks. I wonder if cats are even capable of learning?

entry.title: Bonsai Gardener
entry.content:
The first time I write something on Twitter it is almost always more than 140 characters long. I contract what I can, delete pronouns, pluck out adjectives and remove modifiers until I get there.

I trim, I snip, and I twist. Writing on Twitter is like being a bonsai gardener.

entry.title: Dave Berman has a blog
entry.content:
It’s called mentholmountains.

In the winter of 1995 I wrote my first and only fan letter. It was to Dave Berman, leader of the Silver Jews. A couple of months later I got a reply from him written on a plain ole index card.

Heady times.

Berman broke up the Silver Jews last year and decided to quit the music business. At the time he said he was considering moving on to “screenwriting or muckraking.” Looks like he decided to give the blogging thing a try too.

entry.title: Like Someone from the Showa Period
entry.content:
I had some classical music streaming via the Naxos Music Library app through the iPad during one of my lessons today. The kid I was teaching asked what it was. I didn’t know, I’d just chosen a playlist called ‘Cello Music’, so I told her it was the radio. She seemed to accept that but, at the end of the lesson she said something odd in Japanese.

“You’re like someone from the Showa period.”

“What? What do you mean? The Showa period?”

“You’re listening to the radio. I don’t know if I’ve ever seen a radio.”

entry.title: Tron: Legacy
entry.content:
I went to ‘Tron: Legacy’ with a pretty clear idea of what I was getting into. I expected the visuals to be fantastic, and the story to be very average.

It surpassed my expectations in both regards. The visuals were even more beautiful than I’d hoped. The story and dialogue were much, much worse than I’d feared. So much so that I wish I’d gone to see the dubbed Japanese version.

No, actually, I’d still be able to understand too much of the dialogue. If you want to get the most enjoyment out of ‘Tron: Legacy’ see it dubbed in a language you don’t understand at all. I imagine it would be quite good in French.

entry.title: How to park a car
entry.content:
1. Park the car.
  2. Kill the lights.
  3. Engage the handbrake.
  4. Get out of the car.
  5. Lock the door.
  6. Immediately forget that you’ve locked the door.
  7. Walk into the supermarket, department store, or wherever.
  8. Realize that you don’t remember locking the door.
  9. Walk back to the car.
  10. See that, as usual, the door is locked.
  11. Repeat, four times a week for the rest of your life, because there was that one time eight years ago that you came back to check the lock and it actually was unlocked, and weren’t you lucky you caught that?

One time.
Eight years ago.

entry.title: Painting the bathroom
entry.content:
After four months of procrastination I finally painted the bathroom today and somehow did it without killing myself.

It was a little hairy at times, I had to stand on tiptoes on the rim of the bathtub to reach the ceiling above. I almost lost my balance a couple of times but my ninja training kept me on my feet.

Timewise, it was a big improvement over my last painting effort. That took three days to finish and, truth be told, still isn’t really done. There are little bits of masking tape I’ve not yet removed. The bathroom today only took about six hours to get everything finished and cleaned up.

entry.title: An Unhappy Meal
entry.content:
I used to have a terrible, terrible diet.

McDonalds was my default place for a quick, filling(!) lunch and I always ordered the same thing: a Big Mac, a Double Cheeseburger, Medium Fries, and a cup of coffee. All that weighs in at just under 1,500 calories and I used to polish it off in five, maybe ten minutes.

Jeez Louise!

This is what it looked like:

Yeah, I’m shaking my head too. The scariest thing was that I would eat this without thinking twice.

Over, and over, and over again.

It’s been quite a while since I had this particular culinary combination and I found it really hard to get through. I didn’t look up the calorie info until I’d finished making the video. If I’d known beforehand how bad it was, I don’t think I’d have made this at all.

Guess who’s having broccoli for dinner.

entry.title: Wait up, baldy!
entry.content:
So, I’m coming out of a convenience store this morning. Coming towards the store is a father with his two kids, a boy and a girl, both around seven or eight. Very normal looking family for these parts, dressed in Sunday casual. Tracksuits.

The girl, who is on a bike, is going a little bit fast and crashes into another bike. Her purse and cell phone fly from the basket to the ground. “Pick it up!” she barks, to her father, who does as he’s been told. No hint of anger or annoyance.

As she untangles her bike, her brother and dad head into the store and she shouts “Matte, hage!” A polite translation would be “Wait up, baldy!” Again, no reaction from dad. He keeps walking toward the store. She screams this three more times, increasingly loudly.

Wait up, baldy!
Wait up, baldy!
WAIT UP, BALDY!

A light rain is beginning to fall so I head home to my daughters. I guess they’re not so bad after all.
